awd_abstract_narration:
Many metal surfaces can catalyze important chemical reactions. However, metals with the highest catalytic activity are oftentimes some of the rarest and most expensive elements, such as palladium (Pd) and platinum (Pt). With support from the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Michael Trenary of the University of Illinois at Chicago is exploring a new class of bimetallic surfaces where isolated atoms of catalytically active metals (e.g. Pd) are placed on a less expensive metal, such as copper (Cu).  When these single atom alloys (SSAs) are exposed to hydrogen gas (H2), the Pd atoms dissociate the H2 molecules into H atoms, which spillover onto the Cu surface.  Working with his students, Professor Trenary is using sophisticated spectroscopies to study hydrogenation reactions between the weakly bound H atoms on the surface and small organic molecules.  The project could advance our understanding of catalytic hydrogenation reactions, and could lead to the development of new catalytic materials that minimize the use of expensive metals. The project is also training future scientist and fostering international cooperation through collaboration with researchers in Japan.

The project is using polarization dependent reflection absorption infrared spectroscopy (RAIRS) under ambient pressure conditions to characterize the fundamental steps of hydrogenation reactions. Through analysis of the infrared spectra, Professor Trenary and his students monitor the evolution of gas phase products while also characterizing adsorbed surface species. The methodology is applied to the selective hydrogenation of acrolein to 2-propenol over a Pd-Ag(111) SAA and to CO2 hydrogenation over Pd-Cu(111) and Pt-Cu(111) SAAs. In addition to RAIRS experiments, the properties of the surfaces and their hydrogenation chemistry are being studied with a variety of other techniques including temperature programmed reaction spectroscopy (TPRS), Auger electron spectroscopy (AES), and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM). For each hydrogenation reaction, the objective is to obtain information on the identity of reaction intermediates and to distinguish them from spectator species.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to identify fundamental mechanisms of hydrogenation reactions carried out over a new class of heterogeneous catalysts known as single-atom-alloys (SAAs). An example of a reaction that is enabled by a catalyst is the synthesis of ammonia, which involves the sequential addition of hydrogen to surface nitrogen atoms formed through the dissociation of molecular nitrogen on iron catalysts. It is often claimed that the discovery of the catalytic process for synthesizing ammonia is the most important technological achievement in the history of mankind because of its role in supplying the fertilizer needed to feed the world?s population. Countless other processes of societal benefit employ metal catalysts, and in many cases, the best catalysts employ the rarest and most expensive elements. This is the case in automobile catalytic converters, which use metals such as platinum, palladium, and rhodium. In an SAA, isolated atoms of a catalytically active metal such as palladium or platinum replace an atom in the topmost atomic layer of a relatively inert host metal such as copper. It has been found that even a few surface atoms of an active metal can promote chemical reactions almost as effectively as the pure metal. Furthermore, SAAs appear to be particularly effective in selectively promoting partial hydrogenation reactions as they combine the high catalytic activity of the active metal while retaining the selectivity of the host metal. The research conducted under this grant is premised on the idea that a better fundamental understanding of surface catalyzed chemical reactions will enable the development of new and better catalysts. As part of this project, the surface properties of SAAs composed of palladium and platinum atoms embedded in copper and silver hosts were studied. These studies showed that a palladium copper SAA could selectively hydrogenate propyne to propene without further hydrogenation to propane. The spectroscopic probes used showed that the propyne hydrogenation reaction proceeded even as unreactive carbonaceous deposits formed on the model catalyst surface.

The broader impacts of this grant were in two main areas: human resource development, including providing research opportunities for undergraduates, and enhancing international cooperation. All the research supported by this grant was conducted by graduate students working towards their PhD degrees. One student defended his thesis during the first year of this grant, while two other students defended their theses during the grant?s third year. During the first year and a half, an undergraduate student participated in the research during the summers of 2018 and 209 and a high school student participated in the summer of 2018. However, because of Covid restrictions, undergraduate and high school students were not allowed to engage in laboratory research in the summers of 2020 and 2021. A broader impact goal of NSF is to foster collaborations with international partners. One component of this project has involved joint research with scientists at the Japanese national laboratory known as RIKEN. The PI made two trips to RIKEN during the grant period: A one-month visit in 2019, and a three-day visit in January, 2020. Two jointly coauthored publications between the PI and the RIKEN group acknowledge support from this grant.
